Low-density graph codes that are optimal for source/channel coding and binning

Martin J. Wainwright Emin Martinian
Dept. of Statistics, and Tilda Consulting, Inc.
Dept. of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences Arlington, MA
University of California, Berkeley emin@alum.mit.edu
wainwrig@{eecs,stat}.berkeley.edu

Technical Report 730,

Department of Statistics, UC Berkeley,

April 2007

Abstract

We describe and analyze the joint source/channel coding properties of a class of sparse graphical codes based on compounding a low-density generator matrix (LDGM) code with a low-density parity check (LDPC) code. Our first pair of theorems establish that there exist codes from this ensemble, with all degrees remaining bounded independently of block length, that are simultaneously optimal as both source and channel codes when encoding and decoding are performed optimally. More precisely, in the context of lossy compression, we prove that finite degree constructions can achieve any pair (R,D)ùëÖùê∑(R,D) on the rate-distortion curve of the binary symmetric source. In the context of channel coding, we prove that finite degree codes can achieve any pair (C,p)ùê∂ùëù(C,p) on the capacity-noise curve of the binary symmetric channel. Next, we show that our compound construction has a nested structure that can be exploited to achieve the Wyner-Ziv bound for source coding with side information (SCSI), as well as the Gelfand-Pinsker bound for channel coding with side information (CCSI). Although the current results are based on optimal encoding and decoding, the proposed graphical codes have sparse structure and high girth that renders them well-suited to message-passing and other efficient decoding procedures.

Keywords: Graphical codes; low-density parity check code (LDPC); low-density generator matrix code (LDGM); weight enumerator; source coding; channel coding; Wyner-Ziv problem; Gelfand-Pinsker problem; coding with side information; information embedding; distributed source coding.

1 Introduction

Over the past decade, codes based on graphical constructions, including turbo codes¬†[3] and low-density parity check (LDPC) codes¬†[17], have proven extremely successful for channel coding problems. The sparse graphical nature of these codes makes them very well-suited to decoding using efficient message-passing algorithms, such as the sum-product and max-product algorithms. The asymptotic behavior of iterative decoding on graphs with high girth is well-characterized by the density evolution method¬†[25, 39], which yields a useful design principle for choosing degree distributions. Overall, suitably designed LDPC codes yield excellent practical performance under iterative message-passing, frequently very close to Shannon limits¬†[7].

However, many other communication problems involve aspects of lossy source coding, either alone or in conjunction with channel coding, the latter case corresponding to joint source-channel coding problems. Well-known examples include lossy source coding with side information (one variant corresponding to the Wyner-Ziv problem¬†[45]), and channel coding with side information (one variant being the Gelfand-Pinsker problem¬†[19]). The information-theoretic schemes achieving the optimal rates for coding with side information involve delicate combinations of source and channel coding. For problems of this nature‚Äîin contrast to the case of pure channel coding‚Äîthe use of sparse graphical codes and message-passing algorithm is not nearly as well understood. With this perspective in mind, the focus of this paper is the design and analysis sparse graphical codes for lossy source coding, as well as joint source/channel coding problems. Our main contribution is to exhibit classes of graphical codes, with all degrees remaining bounded independently of the blocklength, that simultaneously achieve the information-theoretic bounds for both source and channel coding under optimal encoding and decoding.

1.1 Previous and ongoing work

A variety of code architectures have been suggested for lossy compression and related problems in source/channel coding. One standard approach to lossy compression is via trellis-code quantization (TCQ)¬†[26]. The advantage of trellis constructions is that exact encoding and decoding can be performed using the max-product or Viterbi algorithm¬†[24], with complexity that grows linearly in the trellis length but exponentially in the constraint length. Various researchers have exploited trellis-based codes both for single-source and distributed compression¬†[6, 23, 37, 46] as well as information embedding problems¬†[5, 15, 42]. One limitation of trellis-based approaches is the fact that saturating rate-distortion bounds requires increasing the trellis constraint length¬†[43], which incurs exponential complexity (even for the max-product or sum-product message-passing algorithms).

Other researchers have proposed and studied the use of low-density parity check (LDPC) codes and turbo codes, which have proven extremely successful for channel coding, in application to various types of compression problems. These techniques have proven particularly successful for lossless distributed compression, often known as the Slepian-Wolf problem¬†[18, 40]. An attractive feature is that the source encoding step can be transformed to an equivalent noisy channel decoding problem, so that known constructions and iterative algorithms can be leveraged. For lossy compression, other work¬†[31] shows that it is possible to approach the binary rate-distortion bound using LDPC-like codes, albeit with degrees that grow logarithmically with the blocklength.

A parallel line of work has studied the use of low-density generator matrix (LDGM) codes, which correspond to the duals of LDPC codes, for lossy compression problems¬†[30, 44, 9, 35, 34]. Focusing on binary erasure quantization (a special compression problem dual to binary erasure channel coding), Martinian and Yedidia¬†[30] proved that LDGM codes combined with modified message-passing can saturate the associated rate-distortion bound. Various researchers have used techniques from statistical physics, including the cavity method and replica methods, to provide non-rigorous analyses of LDGM performance for lossy compression of binary sources¬†[8, 9, 35, 34]. In the limit of zero-distortion, this analysis has been made rigorous in a sequence of papers¬†[12, 32, 10, 14]. Moreover, our own recent work¬†[28, 27] provides rigorous upper bounds on the effective rate-distortion function of various classes of LDGM codes. In terms of practical algorithms for lossy binary compression, researchers have explored variants of the sum-product algorithm¬†[34] or survey propagation algorithms¬†[8, 44] for quantizing binary sources.

1.2 Our contributions

Classical random coding arguments¬†[11] show that random binary linear codes will achieve both channel capacity and rate-distortion bounds. The challenge addressed in this paper is the design and analysis of codes with bounded graphical complexity, meaning that all degrees in a factor graph representation of the code remain bounded independently of blocklength. Such sparsity is critical if there is any hope to leverage efficient message-passing algorithms for encoding and decoding. With this context, the primary contribution of this paper is the analysis of sparse graphical code ensembles in which a low-density generator matrix (LDGM) code is compounded with a low-density parity check (LDPC) code (see¬†Fig.¬†2 for an illustration). Related compound constructions have been considered in previous work, but focusing exclusively on channel coding¬†[16, 36, 41]. In contrast, this paper focuses on communication problems in which source coding plays an essential role, including lossy compression itself as well as joint source/channel coding problems. Indeed, the source coding analysis of the compound construction requires techniques fundamentally different from those used in channel coding analysis. We also note that the compound code illustrated in¬†Fig.¬†2 can be applied to more general memoryless channels and sources; however, so as to bring the primary contribution into sharp focus, this paper focuses exclusively on binary sources and/or binary symmetric channels.

More specifically, our first pair of theorems establish that for any rate R‚àà(0,1)ùëÖ01R\in(0,1), there exist codes from compound LDGM/LDPC ensembles with all degrees remaining bounded independently of the blocklength that achieve both the channel capacity and the rate-distortion bound. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first demonstration of code families with bounded graphical complexity that are simultaneously optimal for both source and channel coding. Building on these results, we demonstrate that codes from our ensemble have a naturally ‚Äúnested‚Äù structure, in which good channel codes can be partitioned into a collection of good source codes, and vice versa. By exploiting this nested structure, we prove that codes from our ensembles can achieve the information-theoretic limits for the binary versions of both the problem of lossy source coding with side information (SCSI, known as the Wyner-Ziv problem¬†[45]), and channel coding with side information (CCSI, known as the Gelfand-Pinsker¬†[19] problem). Although these results are based on optimal encoding and decoding, a code drawn randomly from our ensembles will, with high probability, have high girth and good expansion, and hence be well-suited to message-passing and other efficient decoding procedures.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section¬†2 contains basic background material and definitions for source and channel coding, and factor graph representations of binary linear codes. In Section¬†3, we define the ensembles of compound codes that are the primary focus of this paper, and state (without proof) our main results on their source and channel coding optimality. In Section¬†4, we leverage these results to show that our compound codes can achieve the information-theoretic limits for lossy source coding with side information (SCSI), and channel coding with side information (CCSI). Sections¬†5 and¬†6 are devoted to proofs that codes from the compound ensemble are optimal for lossy source coding (Section¬†5) and channel coding (Section¬†6) respectively. We conclude the paper with a discussion in Section¬†7. Portions of this work have previously appeared as conference papers¬†[28, 29, 27].

2 Background

In this section, we provide relevant background material on source and channel coding, binary linear codes, as well as factor graph representations of such codes.

2.1 Source and channel coding

A binary linear code ‚ÑÇ‚ÑÇ\mathbb{C} of block length nùëõn consists of all binary strings x‚àà{0,1}nùë•superscript01ùëõx\in\{0,1\}^{n} satisfying a set of m<nùëöùëõm<n equations in modulo two arithmetic. More precisely, given a parity check matrix H‚àà{0,1}m√ónùêªsuperscript01ùëöùëõH\in\{0,1\}^{m\times n}, the code is given by the null space

‚ÑÇ‚ÑÇ\displaystyle\mathbb{C} :=:absent\displaystyle:\,= {x‚àà{0,1}n‚à£H‚Äãx=0}.conditional-setùë•superscript01ùëõùêªùë•0\displaystyle\left\{x\in\{0,1\}^{n}\;\mid\;Hx=0\right\}. (1)

Assuming the parity check matrix HùêªH is full rank, the code ‚ÑÇ‚ÑÇ\mathbb{C} consists of 2n‚àím=2n‚ÄãRsuperscript2ùëõùëösuperscript2ùëõùëÖ2^{n-m}=2^{nR} codewords, where R=1‚àímnùëÖ1ùëöùëõR=1-\frac{m}{n} is the code rate.

Channel coding: In the channel coding problem, the transmitter chooses some codeword x‚àà‚ÑÇùë•‚ÑÇx\in\mathbb{C} and transmits it over a noisy channel, so that the receiver observes a noise-corrupted version YùëåY. The channel behavior is modeled by a conditional distribution ‚Ñô‚Äã(y‚à£x)‚Ñôconditionalùë¶ùë•\mathbb{P}(y\mid x) that specifies, for each transmitted sequence YùëåY, a probability distribution over possible received sequences {Y=y}ùëåùë¶\{Y=y\}. In many cases, the channel is memoryless, meaning that it acts on each bit of ‚ÑÇ‚ÑÇ\mathbb{C} in an independent manner, so that the channel model decomposes as ‚Ñô‚Äã(y‚à£x)=‚àèi=1nfi‚Äã(xi;yi)‚Ñôconditionalùë¶ùë•superscriptsubscriptproductùëñ1ùëõsubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë¶ùëñ\mathbb{P}(y\mid x)=\prod_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(x_{i};y_{i}) Here each function fi‚Äã(xi;yi)=‚Ñô‚Äã(yi‚à£xi)subscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë¶ùëñ‚Ñôconditionalsubscriptùë¶ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñf_{i}(x_{i};y_{i})=\mathbb{P}(y_{i}\mid x_{i}) is simply the conditional probability of observing bit yisubscriptùë¶ùëñy_{i} given that xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} was transmitted. As a simple example, in the binary symmetric channel (BSC), the channel flips each transmitted bit xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} with probability pùëùp, so that ‚Ñô‚Äã(yi‚à£xi)=(1‚àíp)‚ÄãùïÄ‚Äã[xi=yi]+p‚Äã(1‚àíùïÄ‚Äã[xi‚â†yi])‚Ñôconditionalsubscriptùë¶ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ1ùëùùïÄdelimited-[]subscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë¶ùëñùëù1ùïÄdelimited-[]subscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùë¶ùëñ\mathbb{P}(y_{i}\mid x_{i})=(1-p)\,\mathbb{I}[x_{i}=y_{i}]+p\left(1-\mathbb{I}[x_{i}\neq y_{i}]\right), where ùïÄ‚Äã(A)ùïÄùê¥\mathbb{I}(A) represents an indicator function of the event Aùê¥A. With this set-up, the goal of the receiver is to solve the channel decoding problem: estimate the most likely transmitted codeword, given by x^:=argmaxx‚àà‚ÑÇ‚Ñô(y‚à£x)\widehat{x}:\,=\arg\max\limits_{x\in\mathbb{C}}\mathbb{P}(y\mid x). The Shannon capacity¬†[11] of a channel specifies an upper bound on the rate RùëÖR of any code for which transmission can be asymptotically error-free. Continuing with our example of the BSC with flip probability pùëùp, the capacity is given by C=1‚àíh‚Äã(p)ùê∂1‚ÑéùëùC=1-h(p), where h(p):=‚àíplog2p‚àí(1‚àíp)log2(1‚àíp)h(p):\,=-p\log_{2}p-(1-p)\log_{2}(1-p) is the binary entropy function.

Lossy source coding: In a lossy source coding problem, the encoder observes some source sequence S‚ààùíÆùëÜùíÆS\in\mathcal{S}, corresponding to a realization of some random vector with i.i.d. elements Si‚àº‚ÑôSsimilar-tosubscriptùëÜùëñsubscript‚ÑôùëÜS_{i}\sim\mathbb{P}_{S}. The idea is to compress the source by representing each source sequence SùëÜS by some codeword x‚àà‚ÑÇùë•‚ÑÇx\in\mathbb{C}. As a particular example, one might be interested in compressing a symmetric Bernoulli source, consisting of binary strings S‚àà{0,1}nùëÜsuperscript01ùëõS\in\{0,1\}^{n}, with each element SisubscriptùëÜùëñS_{i} drawn in an independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) manner from a Bernoulli distribution with parameter p=12ùëù12p=\frac{1}{2}. Given some distortion metric d:ùíÆ√óùíÆ‚Üí‚Ñù+:ùëë‚ÜíùíÆùíÆsubscript‚Ñùd:\mathcal{S}\times\mathcal{S}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{+}, the source encoding problem is to find the codeword with minimal distortion‚Äînamely, the optimal encoding x^:=argminx‚àà‚ÑÇd(S^(x),S)\widehat{x}:\,=\arg\min\limits_{x\in\mathbb{C}}d(\widehat{S}(x),S). Classical rate-distortion theory¬†[11] specifies the optimal trade-offs between the compression rate RR\mathrm{R} and the best achievable average distortion D=ùîº‚Äã[d‚Äã(S^,S)]ùê∑ùîºdelimited-[]ùëë^ùëÜùëÜD=\mathbb{E}[d(\widehat{S},S)], where the expectation is taken over the random source sequences SùëÜS. For instance, to follow up on the Bernoulli compression example, if we use the Hamming metric d‚Äã(S^,S)=1n‚Äã‚àëi=1n|S^i‚àíSi|ùëë^ùëÜùëÜ1ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëõsubscript^ùëÜùëñsubscriptùëÜùëñd(\widehat{S},S)=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}|\widehat{S}_{i}-S_{i}| as the distortion measure, then the rate-distortion function takes the form R‚Äã(D)=1‚àíh‚Äã(D)ùëÖùê∑1‚Ñéùê∑R(D)=1-h(D), where h‚Ñéh is the previously defined binary entropy function.

We now provide definitions of ‚Äúgood‚Äù source and channel codes that are useful for future reference.

Definition 1.

(a) A code family is a good Dùê∑D-distortion binary symmetric source code if for any œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0, there exists a code with rate R<1‚àíh‚Äã(D)+œµR1‚Ñéùê∑italic-œµ\mathrm{R}<1-h\left(D\right)+\epsilon that achieves Hamming distortion less than or equal to Dùê∑D.

2.2 Factor graphs and graphical codes

Both the channel decoding and source encoding problems, if viewed naively, require searching over an exponentially large codebook (since |‚ÑÇ|=2n‚ÄãR‚ÑÇsuperscript2ùëõùëÖ|\mathbb{C}|=2^{nR} for a code of rate RùëÖR). Therefore, any practically useful code must have special structure that facilitates decoding and encoding operations. The success of a large subclass of modern codes in use today, especially low-density parity check (LDPC) codes¬†[17, 38], is based on the sparsity of their associated factor graphs.

Given a binary linear code ‚ÑÇ‚ÑÇ\mathbb{C}, specified by parity check matrix HùêªH, the code structure can be captured by a bipartite graph, in which circular nodes (‚àò\circ) represent the binary values xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} (or columns of HùêªH), and square nodes (‚ñ†‚ñ†\blacksquare) represent the parity checks (or rows of HùêªH). For instance, Fig.¬†1(a) shows the factor graph for a rate R=12R12\mathrm{R}=\frac{1}{2} code in parity check form, with m=6ùëö6m=6 checks acting on n=12ùëõ12n=12 bits. The edges in this graph correspond to 111‚Äôs in the parity check matrix, and reveal the subset of bits on which each parity check acts. The parity check code in Fig.¬†1(a) is a regular code with bit degree 333 and check degree 666. Such low-density constructions, meaning that both the bit degrees and check degrees remain bounded independently of the block length nùëõn, are of most practical use, since they can be efficiently represented and stored, and yield excellent performance under message-passing decoding. In the context of a channel coding problem, the shaded circular nodes at the top of the low-density parity check (LDPC) code in panel (a) represent the observed variables yisubscriptùë¶ùëñy_{i} received from the noisy channel.

Figure¬†1(b) shows a binary linear code represented in factor graph form by its generator matrix Gùê∫G. In this dual representation, each codeword x‚àà{0,1}nùë•superscript01ùëõx\in\{0,1\}^{n} is generated by taking the matrix-vector product of the form G‚Äãzùê∫ùëßGz, where z‚àà{0,1}mùëßsuperscript01ùëöz\in\{0,1\}^{m} is a sequence of information bits, and G‚àà{0,1}n√ómùê∫superscript01ùëõùëöG\in\{0,1\}^{n\times m} is the generator matrix. For the code shown in panel (b), the blocklength is n=12ùëõ12n=12, and information sequences are of length m=9ùëö9m=9, for an overall rate of R=m/n=0.75ùëÖùëöùëõ0.75R=m/n=0.75 in this case. The degrees of the check and variable nodes in the factor graph are dc=3subscriptùëëùëê3d_{c}=3 and dv=4subscriptùëëùë£4d_{v}=4 respectively, so that the associated generator matrix Gùê∫G has dc=3subscriptùëëùëê3d_{c}=3 ones in each row, and dv=4subscriptùëëùë£4d_{v}=4 ones in each column. When the generator matrix is sparse in this setting, then the resulting code is known as a low-density generator matrix (LDGM) code.

2.3 Weight enumerating functions

For future reference, it is useful to define the weight enumerating function of a code. Given a binary linear code of blocklength mùëöm, its codewords xùë•x have renormalized Hamming weights w:=‚Äñx‚Äñ1mw:\,=\frac{\|x\|_{1}}{m} that range in the interval [0,1]01[0,1]. Accordingly, it is convenient to define a function ùïém:[0,1]‚Üí‚Ñù+:subscriptùïéùëö‚Üí01subscript‚Ñù\mathbb{W}_{m}:[0,1]\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{+} that, for each w‚àà[0,1]ùë§01w\in[0,1], counts the number of codewords of weight wùë§w:

ùïém‚Äã(w)subscriptùïéùëöùë§\displaystyle\mathbb{W}_{m}(w) :=:absent\displaystyle:\,= |{x‚àà‚ÑÇ‚à£w=‚åà‚Äñx‚Äñ1m‚åâ}|,conditional-setùë•‚ÑÇùë§subscriptnormùë•1ùëö\displaystyle\left|\left\{x\in\mathbb{C}\;\mid\;w=\left\lceil\frac{\|x\|_{1}}{m}\right\rceil\;\right\}\right|, (2)

where ‚åà‚ãÖ‚åâ‚ãÖ\lceil\cdot\rceil denotes the ceiling function. Although it is typically difficult to compute the weight enumerator itself, it is frequently possible to compute (or bound) the average weight enumerator, where the expectation is taken over some random ensemble of codes. In particular, our analysis in the sequel makes use of the average weight enumerator of a (dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c})-regular LDPC code (see¬†Fig.¬†1(a)), defined as

ùî∏m‚Äã(w;dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùî∏ùëöùë§subscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê\displaystyle\mathbb{A}_{m}(w;d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}) :=:absent\displaystyle:\,= 1m‚Äãlog‚Å°ùîº‚Äã[ùïém‚Äã(w)],1ùëöùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùïéùëöùë§\displaystyle\frac{1}{m}\log\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{W}_{m}(w)\right], (3)

where the expectation is taken over the ensemble of all regular (dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c})-LDPC codes. For such regular LDPC codes, this average weight enumerator has been extensively studied in previous work¬†[17, 22].

3 Optimality of bounded degree compound constructions

In this section, we describe the compound LDGM/LDPC construction that is the focus of this paper, and describe our main results on their source and channel coding optimality.

3.1 Compound construction

Our main focus is the construction illustrated in¬†Fig.¬†2, obtained by compounding an LDGM code (top two layers) with an LDPC code (bottom two layers). The code is defined by a factor graph with three layers: at the top, a vector x‚àà{0,1}nùë•superscript01ùëõx\in\{0,1\}^{n} of codeword bits is connected to a set of nùëõn parity checks, which are in turn connected by a sparse generator matrix Gùê∫G to a vector y‚àà{0,1}mùë¶superscript01ùëöy\in\{0,1\}^{m} of information bits in the middle layer. The information bits yùë¶y are also codewords in an LDPC code, defined by the parity check matrix HùêªH connecting the middle and bottom layers.

In more detail, considering first the LDGM component of the compound code, each codeword x‚àà{0,1}nùë•superscript01ùëõx\in\{0,1\}^{n} in the top layer is connected via the generator matrix G‚àà{0,1}n√ómùê∫superscript01ùëõùëöG\in\{0,1\}^{n\times m} to an information sequence y‚àà{0,1}mùë¶superscript01ùëöy\in\{0,1\}^{m} in the middle layer; more specifically, we have the algebraic relation x=G‚Äãyùë•ùê∫ùë¶x=Gy. Note that this LDGM code has rate RG‚â§mnsubscriptùëÖùê∫ùëöùëõR_{G}\leq\frac{m}{n}. Second, turning to the LDPC component of the compound construction, its codewords correspond to a subset of information sequences y‚àà{0,1}mùë¶superscript01ùëöy\in\{0,1\}^{m} in the middle layer. In particular, any valid codeword yùë¶y satisfies the parity check relation H‚Äãy=0ùêªùë¶0Hy=0, where H‚àà{0,1}m√ókùêªsuperscript01ùëöùëòH\in\{0,1\}^{m\times k} joins the middle and bottom layers of the construction. Overall, this defines an LDPC code with rate RH=1‚àíkmsubscriptùëÖùêª1ùëòùëöR_{H}=1-\frac{k}{m}, assuming that HùêªH has full row rank.

The overall code ‚ÑÇ‚ÑÇ\mathbb{C} obtained by concatenating the LDGM and LDPC codes has blocklength nùëõn, and rate RùëÖR upper bounded by RG‚ÄãRHsubscriptùëÖùê∫subscriptùëÖùêªR_{G}R_{H}. In algebraic terms, the code ‚ÑÇ‚ÑÇ\mathbb{C} is defined as

‚ÑÇ‚ÑÇ\displaystyle\mathbb{C} :=:absent\displaystyle:\,= {x‚àà{0,1}n‚à£x=G‚Äãyfor some¬†y‚àà{0,1}m¬†such thatH‚Äãy=0},conditional-setùë•superscript01ùëõformulae-sequenceùë•ùê∫ùë¶for some¬†y‚àà{0,1}m¬†such thatùêªùë¶0\displaystyle\left\{x\in\{0,1\}^{n}\;\mid\;x=Gy\quad\mbox{for some $y\in\{0,1\}^{m}$ such that}\quad Hy=0\right\}, (4)

where all operations are in modulo two arithmetic.

Our analysis in this paper will be performed over random ensembles of compound LDGM/LDPC ensembles. In particular, for each degree triplet (dc,dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùëêsubscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{c},d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}), we focus on the following random ensemble:

  1. (a)

    For each fixed integer dc‚â•4subscriptùëëùëê4d_{c}\geq 4, the random generator matrix G‚àà{0,1}n√ómùê∫superscript01ùëõùëöG\in\{0,1\}^{n\times m} is specified as follows: for each of the nùëõn rows, we choose dcsubscriptùëëùëêd_{c} positions with replacement, and put a 111 in each of these positions. This procedure yields a random matrix with at most dcsubscriptùëëùëêd_{c} ones per row, since it is possible (although of asymptotically negligible probability for any fixed dcsubscriptùëëùëêd_{c}) that the same position is chosen more than once.

  2. (b)

    For each fixed degree pair (dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}), the random LDPC matrix H‚àà{0,1}k√ómùêªsuperscript01ùëòùëöH\in\{0,1\}^{k\times m} is chosen uniformly at random from the space of all matrices with exactly dvsubscriptùëëùë£d_{v} ones per column, and exactly dc‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëêd^{\prime}_{c} ones per row. This ensemble is a standard (dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c})-regular LDPC ensemble.

We note that our reason for choosing the check-regular LDGM ensemble specified in step (a) is not that it need define a particularly good code, but rather that it is convenient for theoretical purposes. Interestingly, our analysis shows that the bounded degree dcsubscriptùëëùëêd_{c} check-regular LDGM ensemble, even though it is sub-optimal for both source and channel coding in isolation¬†[28, 29], defines optimal source and channel codes when combined with a bottom LDPC code.

3.2 Main results

Our first main result is on the achievability of the Shannon rate-distortion bound using codes from LDGM/LDPC compound construction with finite degrees (dc,dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùëêsubscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{c},d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}). In particular, we make the following claim:

Theorem 1.

Given any pair (R,D)ùëÖùê∑(R,D) satisfying the Shannon bound, there is a set of finite degrees (dc,dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùëêsubscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{c},d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}) and a code from the associated LDGM/LDPC ensemble with rate RùëÖR that is a Dùê∑D-good source code (see Definition¬†1).

In other work¬†[28, 27], we showed that standard LDGM codes from the check-regular ensemble cannot achieve the rate-distortion bound with finite degrees. As will be highlighted by the proof of Theorem¬†1 in Section¬†5, the inclusion of the LDPC lower code in the compound construction plays a vital role in the achievability of the Shannon rate-distortion curve.

Our second main result of this result is complementary in nature to Theorem¬†1, regarding the achievability of the Shannon channel capacity using codes from LDGM/LDPC compound construction with finite degrees (dc,dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùëêsubscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{c},d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}). In particular, we have:

Theorem 2.

For all rate-noise pairs (R,p)ùëÖùëù(R,p) satisfying the Shannon channel coding bound R<1‚àíh‚Äã(p)ùëÖ1‚ÑéùëùR<1-h\left(p\right), there is a set of finite degrees (dc,dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùëêsubscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{c},d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}) and a code from the associated LDGM/LDPC ensemble with rate RùëÖR that is a pùëùp-good channel code (see Definition¬†1).

To put this result into perspective, recall that the overall rate of this compound construction is given by R=RG‚ÄãRHùëÖsubscriptùëÖùê∫subscriptùëÖùêªR=R_{G}R_{H}. Note that an LDGM code on its own (i.e., without the lower LDPC code) is a special case of this construction with RH=1subscriptùëÖùêª1R_{H}=1. However, a standard LDGM of this variety is not a good channel code, due to the large number of low-weight codewords. Essentially, the proof of Theorem¬†2 (see Section¬†6) shows that using a non-trivial LDPC lower code (with RH<1subscriptùëÖùêª1R_{H}<1) can eliminate these troublesome low-weight codewords.

4 Consequences for coding with side information

We now turn to consideration of the consequences of our two main results for problems of coding with side information. It is well-known from previous work¬†[47] that achieving the information-theoretic limits for these problems requires nested constructions, in which a collection of good source codes are nested inside a good channel code (or vice versa). Accordingly, we begin in Section¬†4.1 by describing how our compound construction naturally generates such nested ensembles. In Sections¬†4.2 and¬†4.3 respectively, we discuss how the compound construction can be used to achieve the information-theoretic optimum for binary source coding with side information (a version of the Wyner-Ziv problem¬†[45]), and binary information embedding (a version of ‚Äúdirty paper coding‚Äù, or the Gelfand-Pinsker problem¬†[19]).

4.1 Nested code structure

The structure of the compound LDGM/LDPC construction lends itself naturally to nested code constructions. In particular, we first partition the set of kùëòk lower parity checks into two disjoint subsets K1subscriptùêæ1K_{1} and K2subscriptùêæ2K_{2}, of sizes k1subscriptùëò1k_{1} and k2subscriptùëò2k_{2} respectively, as illustrated in¬†Fig.¬†2. 4.2 Source coding with side information

We begin by showing that the compound construction can be used to perform source coding with side information (SCSI).

4.2.1 Problem formulation

Suppose that we wish to compress a symmetric Bernoulli source S‚àºBer‚Å°(12)similar-toùëÜBer12S\sim\operatorname{Ber}(\frac{1}{2}) so as to be able to reconstruct it with Hamming distortion Dùê∑D. As discussed earlier in Section¬†2, the minimum achievable rate is given by R‚Äã(D)=1‚àíh‚Äã(D)ùëÖùê∑1‚Ñéùê∑R(D)=1-h\left(D\right). In the Wyner-Ziv extension of standard lossy compression¬†[45], there is an additional source of side information about SùëÜS‚Äîsay in the form Z=S‚äïWùëçdirect-sumùëÜùëäZ=S\oplus W where W‚àºBer‚Å°(Œ¥)similar-toùëäBerùõøW\sim\operatorname{Ber}(\delta) is observation noise‚Äîthat is available only at the decoder. See¬†Fig.¬†3 for a block diagram representation of this problem.

For this binary version of source coding with side information (SCSI), it is known¬†[2] that the minimum achievable rate takes the form

RWZ‚Äã(D,p)=l.c.e.‚Å°{h‚Äã(D‚àóp)‚àíh‚Äã(D),(p,0)},\displaystyle R_{\operatorname{WZ}}(D,p)=\operatorname{l.c.e.}\big{\{}h\left(D\ast p\right)-h\left(D\right),\,(p,0)\big{\}}, (8)

where l.c.e.\operatorname{l.c.e.} denotes the lower convex envelope. Note that in the special case p=12ùëù12p=\frac{1}{2}, the side information is useless, so that the Wyner-Ziv rate reduces to classical rate-distortion. In the discussion to follow, we focus only on achieving rates of the form h‚Äã(D‚àóp)‚àíh‚Äã(D)‚Ñé‚àóùê∑ùëù‚Ñéùê∑h\left(D\ast p\right)-h\left(D\right), as any remaining rates on the Wyner-Ziv curve¬†(8) can be achieved by time-sharing with the point (p,0)ùëù0(p,0).

where œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0 is arbitrary. Corollary 1.

There exist finite choices of degrees (dc,dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùëêsubscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{c},d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}) such that the compound LDGM/LDPC construction achieves the Wyner-Ziv bound.

With the channel coding rate R2subscriptR2\mathrm{R}_{2} chosen according to equation¬†(10), the decoder can with high probability recover the quantization S^^ùëÜ\widehat{S}. The overall transmission rate of the scheme is

RtranssubscriptùëÖtrans\displaystyle R_{\operatorname{trans}} =\displaystyle= k2nsubscriptùëò2ùëõ\displaystyle\frac{k_{2}}{n}
=\displaystyle= m‚àík1n‚àím‚àík1‚àík2nùëösubscriptùëò1ùëõùëösubscriptùëò1subscriptùëò2ùëõ\displaystyle\frac{m-k_{1}}{n}-\frac{m-k_{1}-k_{2}}{n}
=\displaystyle= R1‚àíR2subscriptR1subscriptR2\displaystyle\mathrm{R}_{1}-\mathrm{R}_{2}
=\displaystyle= (1‚àíh‚Äã(D)+œµ/2)‚àí(1‚àíh‚Äã(D‚àóp)‚àíœµ/2)1‚Ñéùê∑italic-œµ21‚Ñé‚àóùê∑ùëùitalic-œµ2\displaystyle\left(1-h\left(D\right)+\epsilon/2\right)-\left(1-h\left(D\ast p\right)-\epsilon/2\right)
=\displaystyle= h‚Äã(D‚àóp)‚àíh‚Äã(D)+œµ.‚Ñé‚àóùê∑ùëù‚Ñéùê∑italic-œµ\displaystyle h\left(D\ast p\right)-h\left(D\right)+\epsilon.

Since œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0 was arbitrary, we have established that the scheme can achieve rates arbitrarily close to the Wyner-Ziv bound. ‚àé

4.3 Channel coding with side information

We now show how the compound construction can be used to perform channel coding with side information (CCSI).

4.3.1 Problem formulation

In the binary information embedding problem, given a specified input vector V‚àà{0,1}nùëâsuperscript01ùëõV\in\{0,1\}^{n}, the channel output Z‚àà{0,1}nùëçsuperscript01ùëõZ\in\{0,1\}^{n} is assumed to take the form

Zùëç\displaystyle Z =\displaystyle= V‚äïS‚äïW,direct-sumùëâùëÜùëä\displaystyle V\oplus S\oplus W, (11)

where SùëÜS is a host signal (not under control of the user), and W‚àºBer‚Å°(p)similar-toùëäBerùëùW\sim\operatorname{Ber}(p) corresponds to channel noise. The encoder is free to choose the input vector V‚àà{0,1}nùëâsuperscript01ùëõV\in\{0,1\}^{n}, subject to an average channel constraint

1n‚Äãùîº‚Äã[‚ÄñV‚Äñ1]1ùëõùîºdelimited-[]subscriptnormùëâ1\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\mathbb{E}\left[\|V\|_{1}\right] ‚â§\displaystyle\leq w,ùë§\displaystyle w, (12)

for some parameter w‚àà(0,12]ùë§012w\in(0,\frac{1}{2}]. The goal is to use a channel coding scheme that satisfies this constraint¬†(12) so as to maximize the number of possible messages ùê¶ùê¶\mathbf{m} that can be reliably communicated. Moreover, We write V‚â°Vùê¶ùëâsubscriptùëâùê¶V\equiv V_{\mathbf{m}} to indicate that each channel input is implicitly identified with some underlying message ùê¶ùê¶\mathbf{m}. Given the channel output Z=Vùê¶‚äïS‚äïWùëçdirect-sumsubscriptùëâùê¶ùëÜùëäZ=V_{\mathbf{m}}\oplus S\oplus W, the goal of the decoder is to recover the embedded message ùê¶ùê¶\mathbf{m}. The capacity for this binary information embedding problem¬†[2] is given by

RIE‚Äã(w,p)subscriptùëÖIEùë§ùëù\displaystyle R_{\operatorname{IE}}(w,p) =\displaystyle= u.c.e.‚Å°{h‚Äã(w)‚àíh‚Äã(p),(0,0)},\displaystyle\operatorname{u.c.e.}\big{\{}h\left(w\right)-h\left(p\right),(0,0)\big{\}}, (13)

where u.c.e.\operatorname{u.c.e.} denotes the upper convex envelope. As before, we focus on achieving rates of the form h‚Äã(w)‚àíh‚Äã(p)‚Ñéùë§‚Ñéùëùh\left(w\right)-h\left(p\right), since any remaining points on the curve¬†(13) can be achieved via time-sharing with the (0,0)00(0,0) point.

4.3.2 Coding procedure for CCSI

In order to achieve rates of the form R=h‚Äã(w)‚àíh‚Äã(p)ùëÖ‚Ñéùë§‚ÑéùëùR=h\left(w\right)-h\left(p\right), we again use the compound LDGM/LDPC construction in¬†Fig.¬†2, now according to the following two step procedure.

Step #1: Source coding: The goal of the first stage is to embed the message into the transmitted signal VùëâV via a quantization process. In order to do so, we use the code illustrated in¬†Fig.¬†6(a), specified by the generator matrix Gùê∫G and parity check matrices H1subscriptùêª1H_{1} and H2subscriptùêª2H_{2}. The set K1subscriptùêæ1K_{1} of k1subscriptùëò1k_{1} parity bits associated with the check matrix H1subscriptùêª1H_{1} remain fixed to zero throughout the scheme. On the other hand, we use the remaining k2subscriptùëò2k_{2} lower parity bits associated with H2subscriptùêª2H_{2} to specify a particular message ùê¶‚àà{0,1}k2ùê¶superscript01subscriptùëò2\mathbf{m}\in\{0,1\}^{k_{2}} that the decoder would like to recover. In algebraic terms, the resulting code ‚ÑÇ‚Äã(ùê¶)‚ÑÇùê¶\mathbb{C}(\mathbf{m}) has the form

‚ÑÇ‚Äã(ùê¶)‚ÑÇùê¶\displaystyle\mathbb{C}(\mathbf{m}) :=:absent\displaystyle:\,= {x‚àà{0,1}n‚à£x=G‚Äãyfor some¬†y‚àà{0,1}m¬†such that[H1H2]‚Äãy=[0ùê¶]}.conditional-setùë•superscript01ùëõformulae-sequenceùë•ùê∫ùë¶for some¬†y‚àà{0,1}m¬†such thatmatrixsubscriptùêª1subscriptùêª2ùë¶matrix0ùê¶\displaystyle\left\{x\in\{0,1\}^{n}\;\mid\;x=Gy\quad\mbox{for some $y\in\{0,1\}^{m}$ such that}\quad\begin{bmatrix}H_{1}\\ H_{2}\end{bmatrix}\;y=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ \mathbf{m}\end{bmatrix}\;\right\}. (14)

Since the encoder has access to host signal SùëÜS, it may use this code ‚ÑÇ‚Äã(ùê¶)‚ÑÇùê¶\mathbb{C}(\mathbf{m}) in order to quantize the host signal. After doing so, the encoder has a quantized signal S^ùê¶‚àà{0,1}nsubscript^ùëÜùê¶superscript01ùëõ\widehat{S}_{\mathbf{m}}\in\{0,1\}^{n} and an associated sequence Y^ùê¶‚àà{0,1}msubscript^ùëåùê¶superscript01ùëö\widehat{Y}_{\mathbf{m}}\in\{0,1\}^{m} of information bits such that S^ùê¶=G‚ÄãY^ùê¶subscript^ùëÜùê¶ùê∫subscript^ùëåùê¶\widehat{S}_{\mathbf{m}}=G\,\widehat{Y}_{\mathbf{m}}. Note that the quantized signal (Y^ùê¶,S^ùê¶)subscript^ùëåùê¶subscript^ùëÜùê¶(\widehat{Y}_{\mathbf{m}},\widehat{S}_{\mathbf{m}}) specifies the message ùê¶ùê¶\mathbf{m} in an implicit manner, since ùê¶=H2‚ÄãY^ùê¶ùê¶subscriptùêª2subscript^ùëåùê¶\mathbf{m}=H_{2}\,\widehat{Y}_{\mathbf{m}} by construction of the code ‚ÑÇ‚Äã(ùê¶)‚ÑÇùê¶\mathbb{C}(\mathbf{m}).

Now suppose that we choose n,mùëõùëön,m and kùëòk such that

R1subscriptR1\displaystyle\mathrm{R}_{1} =\displaystyle= m‚àík1‚àík2n=‚ÄÑ1‚àíh‚Äã(w)+œµ/2ùëösubscriptùëò1subscriptùëò2ùëõ1‚Ñéùë§italic-œµ2\displaystyle\frac{m-k_{1}-k_{2}}{n}\;=\;1-h\left(w\right)+\epsilon/2 (15)

for some œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0, then Theorem¬†1 guarantees that there exist finite degrees (dc,dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùëêsubscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{c},d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}) such that the resulting code is a good wùë§w-distortion source code. Otherwise stated, we are guaranteed that w.h.p, the quantization error E:=S‚äïS^E:\,=S\oplus\widehat{S} has average Hamming weight upper bounded by w‚Äãnùë§ùëõwn. Consequently, we may set the channel input VùëâV equal to the quantization noise (V=Eùëâùê∏V=E), thereby ensuring that the average channel constraint¬†(12) is satisfied.

Step #2, Channel coding: In the second phase, the decoder is given a noisy channel observation of the form

Zùëç\displaystyle Z =\displaystyle= E‚äïS‚äïW=S^‚äïW,direct-sumùê∏ùëÜùëädirect-sum^ùëÜùëä\displaystyle E\oplus S\oplus W\;=\;\widehat{S}\oplus W, (16)

and its task is to recover S^^ùëÜ\widehat{S}. In terms of the code architecture, the k1subscriptùëò1k_{1} lower parity bits remain set to zero; the remaining k2subscriptùëò2k_{2} parity bits, which represent the message ùê¶ùê¶\mathbf{m}, are unknown to the coder. The resulting code, as illustrated illustrated in¬†Fig.¬†6(b), can be viewed as channel code with effective rate m‚àík1nùëösubscriptùëò1ùëõ\frac{m-k_{1}}{n}. Now suppose that we choose k1subscriptùëò1k_{1} such that the effective code used by the decoder has rate

R2subscriptR2\displaystyle\mathrm{R}_{2} =\displaystyle= m‚àík1n=1‚àíh‚Äã(p)‚àíœµ/2,ùëösubscriptùëò1ùëõ1‚Ñéùëùitalic-œµ2\displaystyle\frac{m-k_{1}}{n}=1-h\left(p\right)-\epsilon/2, (17)

for some œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0. Since the channel noise WùëäW is Ber‚Å°(p)Berùëù\operatorname{Ber}(p) and the rate R2subscriptR2\mathrm{R}_{2} chosen according to¬†(17), Theorem¬†2 guarantees that the decoder will w.h.p. be able to recover the pair S^^ùëÜ\widehat{S} and Y^^ùëå\widehat{Y}. Moreover, by design of the quantization procedure, we have the equivalence ùê¶=H2‚ÄãY^ùê¶subscriptùêª2^ùëå\mathbf{m}=H_{2}\,\widehat{Y} so that a simple syndrome-forming procedure allows the decoder to recover the hidden message.

Summarizing our findings, we state the following:

Corollary 2.

There exist finite choices of degrees (dc,dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùëêsubscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{c},d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}) such that the compound LDGM/LDPC construction achieves the binary information embedding (Gelfand-Pinsker) bound.

Proof.

With the source coding rate R1subscriptR1\mathrm{R}_{1} chosen according to equation¬†(15), the encoder will return a quantization S^^ùëÜ\widehat{S} of the host signal SùëÜS with average Hamming distortion upper bounded by wùë§w. Consequently, transmitting the quantization error E=S‚äïS^ùê∏direct-sumùëÜ^ùëÜE=S\oplus\widehat{S} will satisfy the average channel constraint¬†(12). With the channel coding rate R2subscriptR2\mathrm{R}_{2} chosen according to equation¬†(17), the decoder can with high probability recover the quantized signal S^^ùëÜ\widehat{S}, and hence the message ùê¶ùê¶\mathbf{m}. Overall, the scheme allows a total of 2k2superscript2subscriptùëò22^{k_{2}} distinct messages to be embedded, so that the effective information embedding rate is

RtranssubscriptùëÖtrans\displaystyle R_{\operatorname{trans}} =\displaystyle= k2nsubscriptùëò2ùëõ\displaystyle\frac{k_{2}}{n}
=\displaystyle= m‚àík1n‚àím‚àík1‚àík2nùëösubscriptùëò1ùëõùëösubscriptùëò1subscriptùëò2ùëõ\displaystyle\frac{m-k_{1}}{n}-\frac{m-k_{1}-k_{2}}{n}
=\displaystyle= R2‚àíR1subscriptR2subscriptR1\displaystyle\mathrm{R}_{2}-\mathrm{R}_{1}
=\displaystyle= (1‚àíh‚Äã(p)‚àíœµ/2)‚àí(1‚àíh‚Äã(w)+œµ/2)1‚Ñéùëùitalic-œµ21‚Ñéùë§italic-œµ2\displaystyle\left(1-h\left(p\right)-\epsilon/2\right)-\left(1-h\left(w\right)+\epsilon/2\right)
=\displaystyle= h‚Äã(w)‚àíh‚Äã(p)+œµ,‚Ñéùë§‚Ñéùëùitalic-œµ\displaystyle h\left(w\right)-h\left(p\right)+\epsilon,

for some œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0. Thus, we have shown that the proposed scheme achieves the binary information embedding bound¬†(13). ‚àé

5 Proof of source coding optimality

This section is devoted to the proof of the previously stated Theorem¬†1 on the source coding optimality of the compound construction.

5.1 Set-up

In establishing a rate-distortion result such as Theorem¬†1, perhaps the most natural focus is the random variable

dn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ)subscriptùëëùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇ\displaystyle d_{n}(S,\mathbb{C}) :=:absent\displaystyle:\,= 1n‚Äãminx‚àà‚ÑÇ‚Å°‚Äñx‚àíS‚Äñ1,1ùëõsubscriptùë•‚ÑÇsubscriptnormùë•ùëÜ1\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\min_{x\in\mathbb{C}}\|x-S\|_{1}, (18)

corresponding to the (renormalized) minimum Hamming distance from a random source sequence S‚àà{0,1}nùëÜsuperscript01ùëõS\in\{0,1\}^{n} to the nearest codeword in the code ‚ÑÇ‚ÑÇ\mathbb{C}. Rather than analyzing this random variable directly, our proof of Theorem¬†1 proceeds indirectly, by studying an alternative random variable.

Given a binary linear code with NùëÅN codewords, let i=0,1,2,‚Ä¶,N‚àí1ùëñ012‚Ä¶ùëÅ1i=0,1,2,\ldots,N-1 be indices for the different codewords. We say that a codeword XisuperscriptùëãùëñX^{i} is distortion Dùê∑D-good for a source sequence SùëÜS if the Hamming distance ‚ÄñXi‚äïS‚Äñ1subscriptnormdirect-sumsuperscriptùëãùëñùëÜ1\|X^{i}\oplus S\|_{1} is at most D‚Äãnùê∑ùëõDn. We then set the indicator random variable Zi‚Äã(D)=1superscriptùëçùëñùê∑1Z^{i}(D)=1 when codeword XisuperscriptùëãùëñX^{i} is distortion Dùê∑D-good. With these definitions, our proof is based on the following random variable:

Tn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ;D)subscriptùëáùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇùê∑\displaystyle T_{n}(S,\mathbb{C};D) :=:absent\displaystyle:\,= ‚àëi=0N‚àí1Zi‚Äã(D).superscriptsubscriptùëñ0ùëÅ1superscriptùëçùëñùê∑\displaystyle\sum_{i=0}^{N-1}Z^{i}(D). (19)

Note that Tn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ;D)subscriptùëáùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇùê∑T_{n}(S,\mathbb{C};D) simply counts the number of codewords that are distortion Dùê∑D-good for a source sequence SùëÜS. Moreover, for all distortions Dùê∑D, the random variable Tn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ;D)subscriptùëáùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇùê∑T_{n}(S,\mathbb{C};D) is linked to dn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ)subscriptùëëùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇd_{n}(S,\mathbb{C}) via the equivalence

‚Ñô‚Äã[Tn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ;D)>0]‚Ñôdelimited-[]subscriptùëáùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇùê∑0\displaystyle\mathbb{P}[T_{n}(S,\mathbb{C};D)>0] =\displaystyle= ‚Ñô‚Äã[dn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ)‚â§D].‚Ñôdelimited-[]subscriptùëëùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇùê∑\displaystyle\mathbb{P}[d_{n}(S,\mathbb{C})\leq D]. (20)

Throughout our analysis of ‚Ñô‚Äã[Tn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ;D)>0]‚Ñôdelimited-[]subscriptùëáùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇùê∑0\mathbb{P}[T_{n}(S,\mathbb{C};D)>0], we carefully track only its exponential behavior. More precisely, the analysis to follow will establish an inverse polynomial lower bound of the form ‚Ñô‚Äã[Tn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ;D)>0]‚â•1/f‚Äã(n)‚Ñôdelimited-[]subscriptùëáùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇùê∑01ùëìùëõ\mathbb{P}[T_{n}(S,\mathbb{C};D)>0]\geq 1/f(n) where f‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùëì‚ãÖf(\cdot) collects various polynomial factors. The following concentration result establishes that the polynomial factors in these bounds can be ignored:

Lemma 1 (Sharp concentration).

Suppose that for some target distortion Dùê∑D, we have

‚Ñô‚Äã[Tn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ;D)>0]‚Ñôdelimited-[]subscriptùëáùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇùê∑0\displaystyle\mathbb{P}[T_{n}(S,\mathbb{C};D)>0] ‚â•\displaystyle\geq 1/f‚Äã(n),1ùëìùëõ\displaystyle 1/f(n), (21)

where f‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùëì‚ãÖf(\cdot) is a polynomial function satisfying log‚Å°f‚Äã(n)=o‚Äã(n)ùëìùëõùëúùëõ\log f(n)=o(n). Then for all œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0, there exists a fixed code ‚ÑÇ¬Ø¬Ø‚ÑÇ\bar{\mathbb{C}} of sufficiently large blocklength nùëõn such that ùîº‚Äã[dn‚Äã(S;‚ÑÇ¬Ø)]‚â§D+œµùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëëùëõùëÜ¬Ø‚ÑÇùê∑italic-œµ\mathbb{E}[d_{n}(S;\bar{\mathbb{C}})]\leq D+\epsilon.

Proof.

Let us denote the random code ‚ÑÇ‚ÑÇ\mathbb{C} as (‚ÑÇ1,‚ÑÇ2)subscript‚ÑÇ1subscript‚ÑÇ2(\mathbb{C}_{1},\mathbb{C}_{2}), where ‚ÑÇ1subscript‚ÑÇ1\mathbb{C}_{1} denotes the random LDGM top code, and ‚ÑÇ2subscript‚ÑÇ2\mathbb{C}_{2} denotes the random LDPC bottom code. Throughout the analysis, we condition on some fixed LDPC bottom code, say ‚ÑÇ2=‚ÑÇ¬Ø2subscript‚ÑÇ2subscript¬Ø‚ÑÇ2\mathbb{C}_{2}=\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2}. We begin by showing that the random variable (dn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ)|‚ÑÇ¬Ø2)conditionalsubscriptùëëùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇsubscript¬Ø‚ÑÇ2(d_{n}(S,\mathbb{C})\;|\;\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2}) is sharply concentrated. In order to do so, we construct a vertex-exposure martingale¬†[33] of the following form. Consider a fixed sequential labelling {1,‚Ä¶,n}1‚Ä¶ùëõ\{1,\ldots,n\} of the top LDGM checks, with check iùëñi associated with source bit SisubscriptùëÜùëñS_{i}. We reveal the check and associated source bit in a sequential manner for each i=1,‚Ä¶,nùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëõi=1,\ldots,n, and so define a sequence of random variables {U0,U1,‚Ä¶,Un}subscriptùëà0subscriptùëà1‚Ä¶subscriptùëàùëõ\{U_{0},U_{1},\ldots,U_{n}\} via U0:=ùîº[dn(S,‚ÑÇ)|‚ÑÇ¬Ø2]U_{0}:\,=\mathbb{E}[d_{n}(S,\mathbb{C})\;|\;\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2}], and

Uisubscriptùëàùëñ\displaystyle U_{i} :=:absent\displaystyle:\,= ùîº‚Äã[dn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ)‚à£S1,‚Ä¶,Si,‚ÑÇ¬Ø2],i=1,‚Ä¶,n.formulae-sequenceùîºdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptùëëùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇsubscriptùëÜ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëÜùëñsubscript¬Ø‚ÑÇ2ùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëõ\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[d_{n}(S,\mathbb{C})\,\mid\;S_{1},\ldots,S_{i},\,\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2}\right],\qquad i=1,\ldots,n. (22)

By construction, we have Un=(dn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ)‚à£‚ÑÇ¬Ø2)subscriptùëàùëõconditionalsubscriptùëëùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇsubscript¬Ø‚ÑÇ2U_{n}=(d_{n}(S,\mathbb{C})\,\mid\,\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2}). Moreover, this sequence satisfies the following bounded difference property: adding any source bit SisubscriptùëÜùëñS_{i} and the associated check in moving from Ui‚àí1subscriptùëàùëñ1U_{i-1} to UisubscriptùëàùëñU_{i} can lead to a (renormalized) change in the minimum distortion of at most ci=1/nsubscriptùëêùëñ1ùëõc_{i}=1/n. Consequently, by applying Azuma‚Äôs inequality¬†[1], we have, for any œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0,

‚Ñô[|(dn(S,‚ÑÇ)‚à£‚ÑÇ¬Ø2)‚àíùîº[dn(S,‚ÑÇ)|‚ÑÇ¬Ø2]|‚â•œµ]\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left[\big{|}(d_{n}(S,\mathbb{C})\,\mid\,\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2})-\mathbb{E}[d_{n}(S,\mathbb{C})\;|\;\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2}]\big{|}\geq\epsilon\right] ‚â§\displaystyle\leq exp‚Å°(‚àín‚Äãœµ2).ùëõsuperscriptitalic-œµ2\displaystyle\exp\left(-n\epsilon^{2}\right). (23)

Next we observe that our assumption¬†(21) of inverse polynomial decay implies that, for at least one bottom code ‚ÑÇ¬Ø2subscript¬Ø‚ÑÇ2\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2},

‚Ñô‚Äã[dn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ)‚â§D‚à£‚ÑÇ¬Ø2]=‚Ñô‚Äã[Tn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ;D)>0‚à£‚ÑÇ¬Ø2]‚Ñôdelimited-[]subscriptùëëùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇconditionalùê∑subscript¬Ø‚ÑÇ2‚Ñôdelimited-[]subscriptùëáùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇùê∑conditional0subscript¬Ø‚ÑÇ2\displaystyle\mathbb{P}[d_{n}(S,\mathbb{C})\leq D\;\mid\;\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2}]\;=\;\mathbb{P}[T_{n}(S,\mathbb{C};D)>0\;\mid\;\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2}] ‚â•\displaystyle\geq 1/g‚Äã(n),1ùëîùëõ\displaystyle 1/g(n), (24)

for some subexponential function gùëîg. Otherwise, there would exist some Œ±>0ùõº0\alpha>0 such that

‚Ñô‚Äã[Tn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ;D)>0‚à£‚ÑÇ¬Ø2]‚â§exp‚Å°(‚àín‚ÄãŒ±)‚Ñôdelimited-[]subscriptùëáùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇùê∑conditional0subscript¬Ø‚ÑÇ2ùëõùõº\mathbb{P}[T_{n}(S,\mathbb{C};D)>0\,\mid\,\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2}]\leq\exp(-n\alpha)

for all choices of bottom code ‚ÑÇ¬Ø2subscript¬Ø‚ÑÇ2\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2}, and taking averages would violate our assumption¬†(21).

Finally, we claim that the concentration result¬†(23) and inverse polynomial bound¬†(24) yield the result. Indeed, if for some œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0, we had D<ùîº‚Äã[dn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ)|‚ÑÇ¬Ø2]‚àíœµùê∑ùîºdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptùëëùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇsubscript¬Ø‚ÑÇ2italic-œµD<\mathbb{E}[d_{n}(S,\mathbb{C})\;|\;\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2}]-\epsilon, then the concentration bound¬†(23) would imply that the probability

‚Ñô‚Äã[dn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ)‚â§D‚à£‚ÑÇ¬Ø2]‚Ñôdelimited-[]subscriptùëëùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇconditionalùê∑subscript¬Ø‚ÑÇ2\displaystyle\mathbb{P}[d_{n}(S,\mathbb{C})\leq D\;\mid\;\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2}] ‚â§\displaystyle\leq ‚Ñô‚Äã[dn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ)‚â§ùîº‚Äã[dn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ)|‚ÑÇ¬Ø2]‚àíœµ‚à£‚ÑÇ¬Ø2]‚Ñôdelimited-[]subscriptùëëùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇùîºdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptùëëùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇsubscript¬Ø‚ÑÇ2conditionalitalic-œµsubscript¬Ø‚ÑÇ2\displaystyle\mathbb{P}[d_{n}(S,\mathbb{C})\leq\mathbb{E}[d_{n}(S,\mathbb{C})\;|\;\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2}]-\epsilon\;\mid\;\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2}]
‚â§\displaystyle\leq ‚Ñô[|(dn(S,‚ÑÇ)‚à£‚ÑÇ¬Ø2)‚àíùîº[dn(S,‚ÑÇ)|‚ÑÇ¬Ø2]|‚â•œµ]\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left[\big{|}(d_{n}(S,\mathbb{C})\,\mid\,\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2})-\mathbb{E}[d_{n}(S,\mathbb{C})\;|\;\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2}]\big{|}\geq\epsilon\right]

decays exponentially, which would contradict the inverse polynomial bound¬†(24) for sufficiently large nùëõn. Thus, we have shown that assumption¬†(21) implies that for all œµ>0italic-œµ0\epsilon>0, there exists a sufficiently large nùëõn and fixed bottom code ‚ÑÇ¬Ø2subscript¬Ø‚ÑÇ2\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2} such that ùîº‚Äã[dn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ)|‚ÑÇ¬Ø2]‚â§D+œµùîºdelimited-[]conditionalsubscriptùëëùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇsubscript¬Ø‚ÑÇ2ùê∑italic-œµ\mathbb{E}[d_{n}(S,\mathbb{C})\;|\;\bar{\mathbb{C}}_{2}]\leq D+\epsilon. If the average over LDGM codes ‚ÑÇ1subscript‚ÑÇ1\mathbb{C}_{1} satisfies this bound, then at least one choice of LDGM top code must also satisfy it, whence we have established that there exists a fixed code ‚ÑÇ¬Ø¬Ø‚ÑÇ\bar{\mathbb{C}} such that ùîº‚Äã[dn‚Äã(S;‚ÑÇ¬Ø)]‚â§D+œµùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëëùëõùëÜ¬Ø‚ÑÇùê∑italic-œµ\mathbb{E}[d_{n}(S;\bar{\mathbb{C}})]\leq D+\epsilon, as claimed. ‚àé

5.2 Moment analysis

In order to analyze the probability ‚Ñô‚Äã[Tn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ;D)>0]‚Ñôdelimited-[]subscriptùëáùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇùê∑0\mathbb{P}[T_{n}(S,\mathbb{C};D)>0], we make use of the moment bounds given in the following elementary lemma:

Lemma 2 (Moment methods).

Given any random variable NùëÅN taking non-negative integer values, there holds

(ùîº‚Äã[N])2ùîº‚Äã[N2]‚â§(a)‚Ñô‚Äã[N>0]‚â§(b)ùîº‚Äã[N].superscriptùëésuperscriptùîºdelimited-[]ùëÅ2ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptùëÅ2‚Ñôdelimited-[]ùëÅ0superscriptùëèùîºdelimited-[]ùëÅ\frac{\left(\mathbb{E}[N]\right)^{2}}{\mathbb{E}[N^{2}]}\;\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(a)}}{{\leq}}\;\mathbb{P}[N>0]\;\stackrel{{\scriptstyle(b)}}{{\leq}}\;\mathbb{E}[N]. (25)
Proof.

The upper bound (b) is an immediate consequence of Markov‚Äôs inequality, whereas the lower bound (a) follows by applying the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality¬†[20] as follows

(ùîº‚Äã[N])2=(ùîº‚Äã[N‚ÄãùïÄ‚Äã[N>0]])2superscriptùîºdelimited-[]ùëÅ2superscriptùîºdelimited-[]ùëÅùïÄdelimited-[]ùëÅ02\displaystyle\left(\mathbb{E}[N]\right)^{2}\;=\;\left(\mathbb{E}\big{[}N\>\mathbb{I}[N>0]\big{]}\right)^{2} ‚â§\displaystyle\leq ùîº‚Äã[N2]‚Äãùîº‚Äã[ùïÄ2‚Äã[N>0]]=ùîº‚Äã[N2]‚Äã‚Ñô‚Äã[N>0].ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptùëÅ2ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptùïÄ2delimited-[]ùëÅ0ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptùëÅ2‚Ñôdelimited-[]ùëÅ0\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[N^{2}]\;\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{I}^{2}[N>0]\right]\;=\;\mathbb{E}[N^{2}]\;\mathbb{P}[N>0].

‚àé

The remainder of the proof consists in applying these moment bounds to the random variable Tn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ;D)subscriptùëáùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇùê∑T_{n}(S,\mathbb{C};D), in order to bound the probability ‚Ñô‚Äã[Tn‚Äã(S,‚ÑÇ;D)>0]‚Ñôdelimited-[]subscriptùëáùëõùëÜ‚ÑÇùê∑0\mathbb{P}[T_{n}(S,\mathbb{C};D)>0]. We begin by computing the first moment:

Lemma 3 (First moment).

For any code with rate RùëÖR, the expected number of Dùê∑D-good codewords scales exponentially as

1n‚Äãlog‚Å°ùîº‚Äã[Tn]1ùëõùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëáùëõ\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\log\mathbb{E}[T_{n}] =\displaystyle= [R‚àí(1‚àíh‚Äã(D))]¬±o‚Äã(1).plus-or-minusdelimited-[]R1‚Ñéùê∑ùëú1\displaystyle\left[\mathrm{R}-(1-h\left(D\right))\right]\;\pm\;o(1). (26)
Proof.

First, by linearity of expectation ùîº‚Äã[Tn]=‚àëi=02n‚ÄãR‚àí1‚Ñô‚Äã[Zi‚Äã(D)=1]=‚ÄÑ2n‚ÄãR‚Äã‚Ñô‚Äã[Z0‚Äã(D)=1]ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëáùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ0superscript2ùëõR1‚Ñôdelimited-[]superscriptùëçùëñùê∑1superscript2ùëõR‚Ñôdelimited-[]superscriptùëç0ùê∑1\mathbb{E}[T_{n}]=\sum_{i=0}^{2^{n\mathrm{R}}-1}\mathbb{P}[Z^{i}(D)=1]\;=\;2^{n\mathrm{R}}\mathbb{P}[Z^{0}(D)=1], where we have used symmetry of the code construction to assert that ‚Ñô‚Äã[Zi‚Äã(D)=1]=‚Ñô‚Äã[Z0‚Äã(D)=1]‚Ñôdelimited-[]superscriptùëçùëñùê∑1‚Ñôdelimited-[]superscriptùëç0ùê∑1\mathbb{P}[Z^{i}(D)=1]=\mathbb{P}[Z^{0}(D)=1] for all indices iùëñi. Now the event {Z0‚Äã(D)=1}superscriptùëç0ùê∑1\{Z^{0}(D)=1\} is equivalent to an i.i.d Bernoulli(12)\frac{1}{2}) sequence of length nùëõn having Hamming weight less than or equal to D‚Äãnùê∑ùëõDn. By standard large deviations theory (either Sanov‚Äôs theorem¬†[11], or direct asymptotics of binomial coefficients), we have

1n‚Äãlog‚Å°‚Ñô‚Äã[Z0‚Äã(D)=1]1ùëõ‚Ñôdelimited-[]superscriptùëç0ùê∑1\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\log\mathbb{P}[Z^{0}(D)=1] =\displaystyle= 1‚àíh‚Äã(D)¬±o‚Äã(1),plus-or-minus1‚Ñéùê∑ùëú1\displaystyle 1-h\left(D\right)\;\pm\;o(1),

which establishes the claim.

‚àé

Unfortunately, however, the first moment ùîº‚Äã[Tn]ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëáùëõ\mathbb{E}[T_{n}] need not be representative of typical behavior of the random variable TnsubscriptùëáùëõT_{n}, and hence overall distortion performance of the code. As a simple illustration, consider an imaginary code consisting of 2n‚ÄãRsuperscript2ùëõR2^{n\mathrm{R}} copies of the all-zeroes codeword. Even for this ‚Äúcode‚Äù, as long as R>1‚àíh‚Äã(D)R1‚Ñéùê∑\mathrm{R}>1-h\left(D\right), the expected number of distortion-Dùê∑D optimal codewords grows exponentially. Indeed, although Tn=0subscriptùëáùëõ0T_{n}=0 for almost all source sequences, for a small subset of source sequences (of probability mass ‚âà2‚àín‚Äã[1‚àíh‚Äã(D)]absentsuperscript2ùëõdelimited-[]1‚Ñéùê∑\approx 2^{-n\,\left[1-h(D)\right]}), the random variable TnsubscriptùëáùëõT_{n} takes on the enormous value 2n‚ÄãRsuperscript2ùëõùëÖ2^{nR}, so that the first moment grows exponentially. However, the average distortion incurred by using this code will be ‚âà0.5absent0.5\approx 0.5 for any rate, so that the first moment is entirely misleading. In order to assess the representativeness of the first moment, one needs to ensure that it is of essentially the same order as the variance, hence the comparison involved in the second moment bound¬†(25)(a).

5.3 Second moment analysis

Our analysis of the second moment begins with the following alternative representation:

Lemma 4.
ùîº[Tn2(D)]=ùîº[Tn(D)](1+{‚àëj‚â†0‚Ñô[Zj(D)=1‚à£Z0(D)=1]}).\mathbb{E}[T_{n}^{2}(D)]\;=\;\mathbb{E}[T_{n}(D)]\,\Biggr{(}1+\Big{\{}\sum_{j\neq 0}\mathbb{P}[Z^{j}(D)=1\,\mid\,Z^{0}(D)=1]\Big{\}}\Biggr{)}. (27)

Based on this lemma, proved in Appendix¬†C, we see that the key quantity to control is the conditional probability ‚Ñô‚Äã[Zj‚Äã(D)=1‚à£Z0‚Äã(D)=1]‚Ñôdelimited-[]superscriptùëçùëóùê∑conditional1superscriptùëç0ùê∑1\mathbb{P}[Z^{j}(D)=1\,\mid\,Z^{0}(D)=1]. It is this overlap probability that differentiates the low-density codes of interest here from the unstructured codebooks used in classical random coding arguments.222In the latter case, codewords are chosen independently from some ensemble, so that the overlap probability is simply equal to ‚Ñô‚Äã[Zj‚Äã(D)=1]‚Ñôdelimited-[]superscriptùëçùëóùê∑1\mathbb{P}[Z^{j}(D)=1]. Thus, for the simple case of unstructured random coding, the second moment bound actually provides the converse to Shannon‚Äôs rate-distortion theorem for the symmetric Bernoulli source. For a low-density graphical code, the dependence between the events {Zj‚Äã(D)=1}superscriptùëçùëóùê∑1\{Z^{j}(D)=1\} and {Z0‚Äã(D)=1}superscriptùëç0ùê∑1\{Z^{0}(D)=1\} requires some analysis.

Before proceeding with this analysis, we require some definitions. Recall our earlier definition¬†(3) of the average weight enumerator associated with an (dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}) LDPC code, denoted by ùî∏m‚Äã(w)subscriptùî∏ùëöùë§\mathbb{A}_{m}(w). Moreover, let us define for each w‚àà[0,1]ùë§01w\in[0,1] the probability

‚Ñö‚Äã(w;D)‚Ñöùë§ùê∑\displaystyle\mathbb{Q}(w;D) :=:absent\displaystyle:\,= ‚Ñô[‚à•X(w)‚äïS‚à•1‚â§Dn‚à£‚à•S‚à•1‚â§Dn],\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left[\|X(w)\oplus S\|_{1}\leq Dn\;\mid\;\|S\|_{1}\leq Dn\right], (28)

Œ¥‚àó‚Äã(w;dc)superscriptùõøùë§subscriptùëëùëê\displaystyle\delta^{*}(w;d_{c}) =\displaystyle= 12[1‚àí(1‚àí2w)dc].\displaystyle\frac{1}{2}\,\biggr{[}1-(1-2\,w)^{d_{c}}\biggr{]}. (29)

Doing so yields

‚àëj‚â†0‚Ñô‚Äã[Zj‚Äã(D)=1‚à£Z0‚Äã(D)=1]subscriptùëó0‚Ñôdelimited-[]superscriptùëçùëóùê∑conditional1superscriptùëç0ùê∑1\displaystyle\sum_{j\neq 0}\mathbb{P}[Z^{j}(D)=1\,\mid\,Z^{0}(D)=1] =\displaystyle= ‚àët=1mùî∏m‚Äã(t/m)‚Äã‚Ñö‚Äã(t/m;D)superscriptsubscriptùë°1ùëösubscriptùî∏ùëöùë°ùëö‚Ñöùë°ùëöùê∑\displaystyle\sum_{t=1}^{m}\mathbb{A}_{m}(t/m)\,\mathbb{Q}(t/m;D)

Consequently, we need to control both the LDPC weight enumerator ùî∏m‚Äã(w)subscriptùî∏ùëöùë§\mathbb{A}_{m}(w) and the probability ‚Ñö‚Äã(w;D)‚Ñöùë§ùê∑\mathbb{Q}(w;D) over the range of possible fractional weights w‚àà[0,1]ùë§01w\in[0,1].

5.4 Bounding the overlap probability

The following lemma, proved in Appendix¬†D, provides a large deviations bound on the probability ‚Ñö‚Äã(w;D)‚Ñöùë§ùê∑\mathbb{Q}(w;D).

Lemma 5.

1n‚Äãlog‚Å°‚Ñö‚Äã(w;D)1ùëõ‚Ñöùë§ùê∑\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\log\mathbb{Q}(w;D) ‚â§\displaystyle\leq F‚Äã(Œ¥‚àó‚Äã(w;dc);D)+o‚Äã(1),ùêπsuperscriptùõøùë§subscriptùëëùëêùê∑ùëú1\displaystyle F(\delta^{*}(w;d_{c});D)+o(1), (30)

Here Œª‚àó:=log[‚àíb+b2‚àí4‚Äãa‚Äãc2‚Äãa]\lambda^{*}:\,=\log\biggr{[}\frac{-b+\sqrt{b^{2}-4ac}}{2a}\biggr{]}, where a:=t(1‚àít)(1‚àíD)a:\,=t\,(1-t)\,(1-D), b:=(1‚àí2D)t2b:\,=(1-2D)t^{2}, and c:=‚àít(1‚àít)Dc:\,=-t\,(1-t)\,D.

We are now equipped to establish the form of the effective rate-distortion function for any compound LDGM/LDPC ensemble. Substituting the alternative form of ùîº‚Äã[Tn2]ùîºdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptùëáùëõ2\mathbb{E}[T_{n}^{2}] from equation¬†(27) into the second moment lower bound¬†(25) yields

1n‚Äãlog‚Å°‚Ñô‚Äã[Tn‚Äã(D)>0]1ùëõ‚Ñôdelimited-[]subscriptùëáùëõùê∑0\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\log\mathbb{P}[T_{n}(D)>0] ‚â•\displaystyle\geq 1n‚Äã[log‚Å°ùîº‚Äã[Tn‚Äã(D)]‚àílog‚Å°{1+‚àëj‚â†0‚Ñô‚Äã[Zj‚Äã(D)=1‚à£Z0‚Äã(D)=1]}]1ùëõdelimited-[]ùîºdelimited-[]subscriptùëáùëõùê∑1subscriptùëó0‚Ñôdelimited-[]superscriptùëçùëóùê∑conditional1superscriptùëç0ùê∑1\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\left[\log\mathbb{E}[T_{n}(D)]-\log\left\{1+\sum_{j\neq 0}\mathbb{P}[Z^{j}(D)=1\,\mid\;Z^{0}(D)=1]\right\}\right] (32)

Figure¬†8 illustrates the behavior of the RHS of equation¬†(33), whose maximum defines the effective rate-distortion function, for the case of LDGM top degree dc=4subscriptùëëùëê4d_{c}=4. Panels (a) and (b) show the cases of distortion D=0.1100ùê∑0.1100D=0.1100 and D=0.3160ùê∑0.3160D=0.3160 respectively, for which the respective Shannon rates are R=0.50ùëÖ0.50R=0.50 and R=0.10ùëÖ0.10R=0.10. Each panel shows two plots, one corresponding the case of uncoded information bits (a naive LDGM code), and the other to using a rate RH=2/3subscriptùëÖùêª23R_{H}=2/3 LDPC code with degrees (dv,dc)=(4,6)subscriptùëëùë£subscriptùëëùëê46(d_{v},d_{c})=(4,6). In all cases, the minimum achievable rate for the given distortion is obtained by taking the maximum for w‚àà[0,0.5]ùë§00.5w\in[0,0.5] of the plotted function. For any choices of Dùê∑D, the plotted curve is equal to the Shannon bound RSha=1‚àíh‚Äã(D)subscriptùëÖSha1‚Ñéùê∑R_{\operatorname{Sha}}=1-h\left(D\right) at w=0ùë§0w=0, and decreases to 00 for w=12ùë§12w=\frac{1}{2}.

Note the dramatic difference between the uncoded and compound constructions (LDPC-coded). In particular, for both settings of the distortion (D=0.1100ùê∑0.1100D=0.1100 and D=0.3160ùê∑0.3160D=0.3160), the uncoded curves rise from their initial values to maxima above the Shannon limit (dotted horizontal line). Consequently, the minimum required rate using these constructions lies strictly above the Shannon optimum. The compound construction curves, in contrast, decrease monotonically from their maximum value, achieved at w=0ùë§0w=0 and corresponding to the Shannon optimum. In the following section, we provide an analytical proof of the fact that for any distortion D‚àà[0,12)ùê∑012D\in[0,\frac{1}{2}), it is always possible to choose finite degrees such that the compound construction achieves the Shannon optimum.

5.5 Finite degrees are sufficient

In order to complete the proof of Theorem¬†1, we need to show that for all rate-distortion pairs (R,D)ùëÖùê∑(R,D) satisfying the Shannon bound, there exist LDPC codes with finite degrees (dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}) and a suitably large but finite top degree dcsubscriptùëëùëêd_{c} such that the compound LDGM/LDPC construction achieves the specified (R,D)ùëÖùê∑(R,D).

Our proof proceeds as follows. Recall that in moving from equation¬†(32) to equation¬†(33), we assumed a bound on the average weight enumerator ùî∏msubscriptùî∏ùëö\mathbb{A}_{m} of the form

1m‚Äãlog‚Å°ùî∏m‚Äã(w)1ùëösubscriptùî∏ùëöùë§\displaystyle\frac{1}{m}\log\mathbb{A}_{m}(w) ‚â§\displaystyle\leq B‚Äã(w;dv,dc‚Ä≤)+o‚Äã(1).ùêµùë§subscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëêùëú1\displaystyle B(w;d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c})+o(1). (34)

For compactness in notation, we frequently write B‚Äã(w)ùêµùë§B(w), where the dependence on the degree pair (dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}) is understood implicitly. In the following paragraph, we specify a set of conditions on this bounding function BùêµB, and we then show that under these conditions, there exists a finite degree dcsubscriptùëëùëêd_{c} such that the compound construction achieves specified rate-distortion point. In Appendix¬†F, we then prove that the weight enumerator of standard regular LDPC codes satisfies the assumptions required by our analysis.

6 Proof of channel coding optimality

In this section, we turn to the proof of the previously stated Theorem¬†2, concerning the channel coding optimality of the compound construction.

If the codeword x‚àà{0,1}nùë•superscript01ùëõx\in\{0,1\}^{n} is transmitted, then the receiver observes V=x‚äïWùëâdirect-sumùë•ùëäV=x\oplus W, where WùëäW is a Ber‚Å°(p)Berùëù\operatorname{Ber}(p) random vector. Our goal is to bound the probability that maximum likelihood (ML) decoding fails where the probability is taken over the randomness in both the channel noise and the code construction. To simplify the analysis, we focus on the following sub-optimal (non-ML) decoding procedure. Let œµnsubscriptitalic-œµùëõ\epsilon_{n} be any non-negative sequence such that œµn/n‚Üí0‚Üísubscriptitalic-œµùëõùëõ0\epsilon_{n}/n\rightarrow 0 but œµn2/n‚Üí+‚àû‚Üísuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œµùëõ2ùëõ\epsilon_{n}^{2}/n\rightarrow+\infty‚Äîsay for instance, œµn=n2/3subscriptitalic-œµùëõsuperscriptùëõ23\epsilon_{n}=n^{2/3}.

Definition 2 (Decoding Rule:).

With the threshold d(n):=pn+œµnd(n):\,=pn+\epsilon_{n}, decode to codeword xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} ‚áîiff\iff ‚Äñxi‚äïV‚Äñ1‚â§d‚Äã(n)subscriptnormdirect-sumsubscriptùë•ùëñùëâ1ùëëùëõ\|x_{i}\oplus V\|_{1}\leq d(n), and no other codeword is within d‚Äã(n)ùëëùëõd(n) of VùëâV.

The extra term œµnsubscriptitalic-œµùëõ\epsilon_{n} in the threshold d‚Äã(n)ùëëùëõd(n) is chosen for theoretical convenience. Using the following two lemmas, we establish that this procedure has arbitrarily small probability of error, whence ML decoding (which is at least as good) also has arbitrarily small error probability.

Lemma 7.

‚àé

7 Discussion

In this paper, we established that it is possible to achieve both the rate-distortion bound for symmetric Bernoulli sources and the channel capacity for the binary symmetric channel using codes with bounded graphical complexity. More specifically, we have established that there exist low-density generator matrix (LDGM) codes and low-density parity check (LDPC) codes with finite degrees that, when suitably compounded to form a new code, are optimal for both source and channel coding. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first demonstration of classes of codes with bounded graphical complexity that are optimal as source and channel codes simultaneously. We also demonstrated that this compound construction has a naturally nested structure that can be exploited to achieve the Wyner-Ziv bound¬†[45] for lossy compression of binary data with side information, as well as the Gelfand-Pinsker bound¬†[19] for channel coding with side information.

Since the analysis of this paper assumed optimal decoding and encoding, the natural next step is the development and analysis of computationally efficient algorithms for encoding and decoding. Encouragingly, the bounded graphical complexity of our proposed codes ensures that they will, with high probability, have high girth and good expansion, thus rendering them well-suited to message-passing and other efficient decoding procedures. For pure channel coding, previous work¬†[16, 36, 41] has analyzed the performance of belief propagation when applied to various types of compound codes, similar to those analyzed in this paper. On the other hand, for pure lossy source coding, our own past work¬†[44] provides empirical demonstration of the feasibility of modified message-passing schemes for decoding of standard LDGM codes. It remains to extend both these techniques and their analysis to more general joint source/channel coding problems, and the compound constructions analyzed in this paper.

Appendix A Basic property of LDGM codes

For a given weight w‚àà(0,1)ùë§01w\in(0,1), suppose that we enforce that the information sequence y‚àà{0,1}mùë¶superscript01ùëöy\in\{0,1\}^{m} has exactly ‚åàw‚Äãm‚åâùë§ùëö\lceil wm\rceil ones. Conditioned on this event, we can then consider the set of all codewords X‚Äã(w)‚àà{0,1}nùëãùë§superscript01ùëõX(w)\in\{0,1\}^{n}, where we randomize over low-density generator matrices Gùê∫G chosen as in step (a) above. Note for any fixed code, X‚Äã(w)ùëãùë§X(w) is simply some codeword, but becomes a random variable when we imagine choosing the generator matrix Gùê∫G randomly. The following lemma characterizes this distribution as a function of the weight wùë§w and the LDGM top degree dcsubscriptùëëùëêd_{c}:

Lemma 9.

Given a binary vector y‚àà{0,1}mùë¶superscript01ùëöy\in\{0,1\}^{m} with a fraction wùë§w of ones, the distribution of the random LDGM codeword X‚Äã(w)ùëãùë§X(w) induced by yùë¶y is i.i.d. Bernoulli with parameter Œ¥‚àó(w;dc)=12[1‚àí(1‚àí2w)dc]\delta^{*}(w;d_{c})=\frac{1}{2}\,\biggr{[}1-(1-2\,w)^{d_{c}}\biggr{]}.

Proof.

Given a fixed sequence y‚àà{0,1}mùë¶superscript01ùëöy\in\{0,1\}^{m} with a fraction wùë§w ones, the random codeword bit Xi‚Äã(w)subscriptùëãùëñùë§X_{i}(w) at bit iùëñi is formed by connecting dcsubscriptùëëùëêd_{c} edges to the set of information bits.333In principle, our procedure allows two different edges to choose the same information bit, but the probability of such double-edges is asymptotically negligible. Each edge acts as an i.i.d. Bernoulli variable with parameter wùë§w, so that we can write

Xi‚Äã(w)subscriptùëãùëñùë§\displaystyle X_{i}(w) =\displaystyle= V1‚äïV2‚äï‚Ä¶‚äïVdc,direct-sumsubscriptùëâ1subscriptùëâ2‚Ä¶subscriptùëâsubscriptùëëùëê\displaystyle V_{1}\oplus V_{2}\oplus\ldots\oplus V_{d_{c}}, (45)

where each Vk‚àºBer‚Å°(w)similar-tosubscriptùëâùëòBerùë§V_{k}\sim\operatorname{Ber}(w) is independent and identically distributed. A straightforward calculation using z-transforms (see¬†[17]) or Fourier transforms over G‚ÄãF‚Äã(2)ùê∫ùêπ2GF(2) yields that Xi‚Äã(w)subscriptùëãùëñùë§X_{i}(w) is Bernoulli with parameter Œ¥‚àó‚Äã(w;dc)superscriptùõøùë§subscriptùëëùëê\delta^{*}(w;d_{c}) as defined. ‚àé

Appendix B Bounds on binomial coefficients

The following bounds on binomial coefficients are standard (see Chap. 12,¬†[11]):

h‚Äã(kn)‚àílog‚Å°(n+1)n‚â§1n‚Äãlog‚Å°(nk)‚â§h‚Äã(kn).‚Ñéùëòùëõùëõ1ùëõ1ùëõbinomialùëõùëò‚Ñéùëòùëõh\left(\frac{k}{n}\right)-\frac{\log(n+1)}{n}\;\leq\;\frac{1}{n}\log{n\choose k}\;\leq\;h\left(\frac{k}{n}\right). (46)

Here, for Œ±‚àà(0,1)ùõº01\alpha\in(0,1), the quantity h(Œ±):=‚àíŒ±logŒ±‚àí(1‚àíŒ±)log(1‚àíŒ±)h(\alpha):\,=-\alpha\log\alpha-(1-\alpha)\log(1-\alpha) is the binomial entropy function.

where the function Gùê∫G takes the form

(52)

Finally, we establish that the solution (u‚àó,Œª‚àó)superscriptùë¢superscriptùúÜ(u^{*},\lambda^{*}) to the min-max saddle point problem¬†(51) is unique, and specified by u‚àó=Dsuperscriptùë¢ùê∑u^{*}=D and Œª‚àósuperscriptùúÜ\lambda^{*} as in Lemma¬†5. First of all, observe that for any Œ¥‚àà(0,1)ùõø01\delta\in(0,1), the function Gùê∫G is continuous, strictly concave in uùë¢u and strictly convex in ŒªùúÜ\lambda. (The strict concavity follows since h‚Äã(u)‚Ñéùë¢h\left(u\right) is strictly concave with the remaining terms linear; the strict convexity follows since cumulant generating functions are strictly convex.) Therefore, for any fixed Œª<0ùúÜ0\lambda<0, the maximum over u‚àà[0,D]ùë¢0ùê∑u\in[0,D] is always achieved. On the other hand, for any D>0ùê∑0D>0, u‚àà[0,D]ùë¢0ùê∑u\in[0,D] and Œ¥‚àà(0,1)ùõø01\delta\in(0,1), we have G‚Äã(u;Œª;t)‚Üí+‚àû‚Üíùê∫ùë¢ùúÜùë°G(u;\lambda;t)\rightarrow+\infty as Œª‚Üí‚àí‚àû‚ÜíùúÜ\lambda\rightarrow-\infty, so that the infimum is either achieved at some Œª‚àó<0superscriptùúÜ0\lambda^{*}<0, or at Œª‚àó=0superscriptùúÜ0\lambda^{*}=0. We show below that it is always achieved at an interior point Œª‚àó<0superscriptùúÜ0\lambda^{*}<0. Thus far, using standard saddle point theory¬†[21], we have established the existence and uniqueness of the saddle point solution (u‚àó,Œª‚àó)superscriptùë¢superscriptùúÜ(u^{*},\lambda^{*}).

To verify the fixed point conditions, we compute partial derivatives in order to find the optimum. First, considering uùë¢u, we compute

‚àÇG‚àÇu‚Äã(u,Œª;Œ¥)ùê∫ùë¢ùë¢ùúÜùõø\displaystyle\frac{\partial G}{\partial u}(u,\lambda;\delta) =\displaystyle= log‚Å°1‚àíuu+log‚Å°ùïÑU‚Äã(Œª)‚àílog‚Å°ùïÑV‚Äã(Œª)1ùë¢ùë¢subscriptùïÑùëàùúÜsubscriptùïÑùëâùúÜ\displaystyle\log\frac{1-u}{u}+\log\mathbb{M}_{U}(\lambda)-\log\mathbb{M}_{V}(\lambda)

Appendix E Proof of Lemma¬†6

A straightforward calculation yields that

G‚Äã(12)=F‚Äã(Œ¥‚àó‚Äã(12;dc);D)=F‚Äã(12;D)=‚àí(1‚àíh‚Äã(D))ùê∫12ùêπsuperscriptùõø12subscriptùëëùëêùê∑ùêπ12ùê∑1‚Ñéùê∑G(\frac{1}{2})=F(\delta^{*}(\frac{1}{2};d_{c});D)=F(\frac{1}{2};D)=-\left(1-h\left(D\right)\right)

as claimed. Turning next to the derivatives, we note that by inspection, the solution Œª‚àó‚Äã(t)superscriptùúÜùë°\lambda^{*}(t) defined in Lemma¬†5 is twice continuously differentiable as a function of tùë°t. Appendix F Regular LDPC codes are sufficient

Consider a regular (dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}) code from the standard Gallager LDPC ensemble. In order to complete the proof of Theorem¬†1, we need to show for suitable choices of degree (dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}), the average weight enumerator of these codes can be suitably bounded, as in equation¬†(34), by a function BùêµB that satisfies the conditions specified in Section¬†5.5.

It can be shown¬†[17, 22] that for even degrees dc‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëêd^{\prime}_{c}, the average weight enumerator of the regular Gallager ensemble, for any block length mùëöm, satisfies the bound

1m‚Äãlog‚Å°ùî∏m‚Äã(w)1ùëösubscriptùî∏ùëöùë§\displaystyle\frac{1}{m}\log\mathbb{A}_{m}(w) =\displaystyle= B‚Äã(w;dv,dc‚Ä≤)+o‚Äã(1).ùêµùë§subscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëêùëú1\displaystyle B(w;d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c})+o(1).

The function BùêµB in this relation is defined for w‚àà[0,12]ùë§012w\in[0,\frac{1}{2}] as

and by B‚Äã(w)=B‚Äã(w‚àí12)ùêµùë§ùêµùë§12B(w)=B(w-\frac{1}{2}) for w‚àà[12,1]ùë§121w\in[\frac{1}{2},1]. (57)

Some numerical computation for RH=0.5subscriptùëÖùêª0.5R_{H}=0.5 and different choices (dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}) yields the curves shown in¬†Fig.¬†9.

We now show that for suitable choices of degree (dv,dc‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùë£subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëê(d_{v},d^{\prime}_{c}), the function BùêµB defined in equation¬†(56) satisfies the four assumptions specified in Section¬†5.5. First, for even degrees dc‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùëë‚Ä≤ùëêd^{\prime}_{c}, the function BùêµB is symmetric about w=12ùë§12w=\frac{1}{2}, so that assumption (A1) holds. Secondly, we have B‚Äã(w)‚â§RHùêµùë§subscriptùëÖùêªB(w)\leq R_{H}, and moreover, for w=12ùë§12w=\frac{1}{2}, the optimal Œª‚àó‚Äã(12)=0superscriptùúÜ120\lambda^{*}(\frac{1}{2})=0, so that B‚Äã(12)=RHùêµ12subscriptùëÖùêªB(\frac{1}{2})=R_{H}, and assumption (A3) is satisfied. Next, it is known from the work of Gallager¬†[17], and moreover is clear from the plots in¬†Fig.¬†9, that LDPC codes with dv>2subscriptùëëùë£2d_{v}>2 have linear minimum distance, so that assumption (A4) holds.

The final condition to verify is assumption (A2), concerning the differentiability of BùêµB. We summarize this claim in the following:

Lemma 10.

The function BùêµB is twice continuously differentiable on (0,1)01(0,1), and in particular we have

B‚Ä≤‚Äã(12)=‚ÄÑ0,andB‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Äã(12)<‚ÄÑ0.formulae-sequencesuperscriptùêµ‚Ä≤12‚ÄÑ0andsuperscriptùêµ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤12‚ÄÑ0B^{\prime}(\frac{1}{2})\;=\;0,\qquad\mbox{and}\qquad B^{\prime\prime}(\frac{1}{2})\;<\;0. (58)
Proof.

Note that for each fixed w‚àà(0,1)ùë§01w\in(0,1), the function

is strictly convex and twice continuously differentiable as a function of ŒªùúÜ\lambda. Moreover, the function f‚àó(w):=infŒª‚â§0{f(Œª)‚àíŒªw}f^{*}(w):\,=\inf_{\lambda\leq 0}\ \{f(\lambda)-\lambda w\} corresponds to the conjugate dual¬†[21] of f‚Äã(Œª)+ùïÄ‚â§0‚Äã(Œª)ùëìùúÜsubscriptùïÄabsent0ùúÜf(\lambda)+\mathbb{I}_{\leq 0}(\lambda). Since the optimum is uniquely attained for each w‚àà(0,1)ùë§01w\in(0,1), an application of Danskin‚Äôs theorem¬†[4] yields that f‚àósuperscriptùëìf^{*} is differentiable with dd‚Äãw‚Äãf‚àó‚Äã(w)=‚àíŒª‚àó‚Äã(w)ùëëùëëùë§superscriptùëìùë§superscriptùúÜùë§\frac{d}{dw}f^{*}(w)=-\lambda^{*}(w), where Œª‚àósuperscriptùúÜ\lambda^{*} is defined by equation¬†(57). Putting together the pieces, we have B‚Ä≤‚Äã(w)=(1‚àídv)‚Äãh‚Ä≤‚Äã(w)‚àídv‚ÄãŒª‚àó‚Äã(w)superscriptùêµ‚Ä≤ùë§1subscriptùëëùë£superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤ùë§subscriptùëëùë£superscriptùúÜùë§B^{\prime}(w)=(1-d_{v})h^{\prime}(w)-d_{v}\lambda^{*}(w). Evaluating at w=12ùë§12w=\frac{1}{2} yields B‚Ä≤‚Äã(12)=0‚àídv‚ÄãŒª‚àó‚Äã(0)=0superscriptùêµ‚Ä≤120subscriptùëëùë£superscriptùúÜ00B^{\prime}(\frac{1}{2})=0-d_{v}\lambda^{*}(0)=0 as claimed.

We now claim that Œª‚àó‚Äã(w)superscriptùúÜùë§\lambda^{*}(w) is differentiable. Indeed, let us write the defining relation¬†(57) for Œª‚àó‚Äã(w)superscriptùúÜùë§\lambda^{*}(w) as F‚Äã(Œª,w)=0ùêπùúÜùë§0F(\lambda,w)=0 where F(Œª,w):=f‚Ä≤(Œª)‚àíwF(\lambda,w):\,=f^{\prime}(\lambda)-w. Hence, combined with our earlier calculation of B‚Ä≤superscriptùêµ‚Ä≤B^{\prime}, we conclude that B‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Äã(w)=(1‚àídv)‚Äãh‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Äã(w)‚àídv‚Äã1f‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Äã(Œª‚Äã(w))superscriptùêµ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ùë§1subscriptùëëùë£superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ùë§subscriptùëëùë£1superscriptùëì‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ùúÜùë§B^{\prime\prime}(w)=(1-d_{v})h^{\prime\prime}(w)-d_{v}\frac{1}{f^{\prime\prime}(\lambda(w))}. whence
